Building Capacity for Statistics in the Pacific

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  supports  the  implementation  of  the  Pacific 
Approach 2010–2014 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)1 which was endorsed by all Pacific 
developing member country (DMC) governments in September 2009 and by ADB’s Board of 
Directors in November 2009. The 2009 Pacific Forum Economic Ministers Meeting requested 
support  for  strengthening  statistics  capacity  within  Pacific  DMCs.  The  TA  supports 
implementation of the Ten-Year Pacific Statistics Strategy (TYPSS), which was endorsed by the 
heads of planning and statistics in July 2010, and the TYPSS Action Plan Phase 1.2 Fact finding 
was conducted in April 2010 with representatives of the governments of Nauru, Samoa, and 
Vanuatu.  A  draft  concept  paper,  under  the  title  Further  Strengthening  Statistics  and  Policy 
Settings in the Pacific, was submitted to Pacific DMC governments and to national and regional 
public policy agencies for comment. Pacific DMC governments concur with the impact, outcome, 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Economies in all 14 Pacific DMCs can reach increased levels of growth and development, 
accompanied  by  greater  prosperity,  if  better  policies  and  institutions  are  put  in  place  and 
sustained  (footnote  1).  However,  as  both  ADB  and  the  World  Bank  record  in  their  annual 
assessments of policy and institutional settings, policies are commonly not supportive of growth 
and development in the Pacific DMCs.4 Good governance and improved policy and institutional 
settings are essential for growth but these can only be effectively formulated, implemented, and 
monitored if supported by accurate and timely statistical information and analysis. There is a 
growing demand for improved public policy informed by robust statistical information. 
 
3.  Many Pacific DMCs are characterized by poor capacity in policy formulation and public 
sector management, including weak decision making in the public interest. A lack of social and 
economic data further impedes the ability of governments and development partners to analyze 
key development issues to inform policy, strengthen organizational systems, and improve service 
delivery.  
 
4.  The governments of the Pacific DMCs have struggled to build, maintain, and update 
adequate statistical databases, including gender statistics, that inform government leadership of 
key policy issues and concerns. In the absence of sufficient government capacity to construct 
statistical databases and to analyze and formulate better policy and institutional settings, it has 
long been left to development partners to support the governments of the Pacific DMCs with such 
assessments and build government capacities. 
 
5.  The impetus for creating sustained improvements in the capacity of Pacific DMCs to 
generate and analyze statistical information comes from the demand of Pacific leaders for better 
information to improve policy formulation and service delivery of government functions. Moreover, 
regional  demand  for  common  statistics  infrastructure,  common  systems  and  tools,  and

6.  In response, the Pacific heads of planning and statistics developed the TYPSS which was 
endorsed at the heads of planning and statistics meeting in July 2010. The TYPSS provides a 
framework and governance structure to improve national capacity through regional coordination 
and integration. A detailed and costed action plan for phase 1 of the TYPSS has been endorsed 
by Pacific DMC members, technical agencies, and development partners. The framework and 
action  plan  encompasses  (i)  improving  capacity  utilizing  development  partner  expertise  and 
through  south–south  cooperation;  (ii)  developing  common  standards,  methodologies,  and 
infrastructure; (iii) using a programmatic approach to household surveys; (iv) improving economic 
and  social  statistics  in  the  region;  (v)  developing  new  instruments  to  meet  Millennium 
Development Goals reporting and other periodic series in a timely manner; and (vi) improving 
dissemination of data and analysis. 
 
7.  In conjunction with other development partners, the Pacific Financial Technical Assistance 
Centre  (PFTAC),5 and  the  Statistics  and  Demography  Unit  of  the  Secretariat  of  the  Pacific 
Community (SPC), ADB has been working with the statistics departments of all Pacific DMC 
governments to strengthen key statistical data sets and domestic capacities to undertake such 
work.6 Previous  technical  assistance  has  had  mixed  results.  Numerous  valuable  statistical 
products  have  been  developed.  These  have  been  used  to  improve  policy  formulation  and 
implementation. There has been improvement of Pacific DMC capacity but without continued 
support this will never be sustained. 
 
8.  Lessons learned through previous TA projects have been incorporated. These lessons are 
the need for (i) greater regional and development partner cooperation, (ii) implementation of a 
regional plan for technical and financial support, (iii) greater flexibility in timing of activities, and (iv) 
developing regional capacity and supporting capacity development through regional expertise 
within national statistics offices (NSOs). Many countries’ do NSOs not have the human and 
financial resources to prepare the number and variety of statistical products demanded of them. 
This  results  in  competing  priorities  and  inefficient  delivery  of  outputs.  Time  lags  between 
statistical surveys limit skill retention. Personnel movements have also hampered the creation of 
a skilled cadre of individuals within the individual NSOs.  
 
9.  The TYPSS Phase 1 Action Plan (2011–2014) addresses these problems through a 
regional  approach  to  strengthening  statistics  capacity.  It  brings  together  all  the  NSOs  and 
development  partners  in  support  of  a  programmed  approach  within  the  region.  Its  agreed 
objectives are that (i) countries undertake key statistical collections as scheduled, (ii) countries 
produce  the  agreed  core  set  of  statistics  across  key  sectors,  (iii)  countries  have  their  own 
capacity  or  are  accessing  regional  capacity  to  undertake  agreed  core  and  some  specialist 
statistical functions, (iv) data accessibility and utilization is improved, (v) new and innovative 
statistical tools and systems are introduced, and (vi) national and regional statistics governance is 
functioning effectively. 
 
                                                 
5  PFTAC engagement is coordinated with the International Monetary Fund which provides technical back-up. 
6  Earlier TAs include: ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building and Regional Cooperation for Economic 
Statistics  in  Selected  Pacific  Developing  Member  Countries.  Manila  (TA  6009-REG);  ADB.  2004.  Technical 
Assistance for Strengthening Poverty Based Analysis in the Pacific. Manila (TA 6157-REG); ADB. 2005. Technical 
Assistance for Demographic and Health Survey in Pacific Island Countries. Manila (TA 6258-REG); and ADB. 2007. 
Technical Assistance for Support for Results Based Management in the Pacific. Manila (TA 6414-REG).

3 
10.  The  region  will  work  collaboratively  through  the  TYPSS  Pacific  Statistics  Steering 
Committee  (PSSC)  to  achieve  these  objectives.7 External  support  and  collaboration  will  be 
utilized to strengthen capacity and deliver statistical services through sharing resources within the 
region, developing common tools and approaches, and programming external resources on a 
regional basis to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of this support. An action plan with cost 
estimates for phase 1 has been developed, which identifies institutions responsible for actions. A 
monitoring and evaluation framework, endorsed by the TYPSS PSSC, to facilitate the PSSC’s 
management of the TYPSS is also incorporated into the phase 1 action plan. 
 
11.  Nevertheless, the sector remains underfunded. External financing will still be required to 
meet the high costs of conducting surveys and other activities including capacity building.8 While 
south-south cooperation will extend the skills already in the region to other Pacific DMCs, the 
costs of this collaboration will need to be supported. Development partners will continue to 
support very specialized training, although this need is declining.  
 
12.  Ongoing support is consistent with ADB’s long term support to strengthening statistics in 
the Pacific. It is consistent with the Pacific Approach 2010–2014. The TA will contribute to these 
financing gaps and continue to provide technical support to strengthening statistics in the Pacific. 
The TA will support some of the financing and technical assistance gaps identified in the TYPSS 
and coordinate this support within the region and with other development partners.9 By improving 
the quality of statistics in the Pacific and by working towards sustained statistical capacity within 
Pacific DMCs, greater evidence-based policy development is possible. Moreover, timely statistics 
will improve the quality of service delivery in the region. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The TA impact will be that Pacific DMC governments adopt evidence-based policies in 
selected areas. These policies will be based on improved social and economic data developed 
through the TA. The outcome is that NSOs provide accurate and comprehensive social and 
economic indicators. The TA will build capacity in Pacific DMCs to collect and compile robust 
social and economic statistics and present these in a timely manner. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The methodology for the TA is to target specific unfunded gaps in the TYPSS which 
provide direct and immediate benefits to Pacific DMCs. The outputs and activities are also 
directed towards implementing the TYPSS Phase 1 Action Plan’s early and initial activities so that 
there is a sound basis for further capacity building during the remaining 4 years of phase 1. 
 
15.  The TA will therefore support the ongoing regional survey plan by financing the survey 
costs in two of household income and expenditure surveys (HIES) and two of the demographic 
and health surveys (DHS). ADB has supported HIES and DHS over the past decade. To place 
capacity building activities under the TYPSS on firm footing for future support, the TA will also

prepare economic statistics development strategies in each Pacific DMC, capacity assessments, 
and skill audits. These activities will result in: (i) surveys being undertaken and the data being 
available, (ii) an improvement of economic statistics and the integrity of economic data, and (iii) 
improved capacity in economic and household statistics. The TA will also include resources to 
facilitate integration of the TA with the resources and assistance of other development partners 
and NSOs to implement the TYPSS in a coordinated regional approach. 
 
16.  Delivering  household  surveys. Many social and economic statistics are derived, or 
verified, through household surveys conducted every 5–10 years. The TA will support the Pacific 
household survey program encompassing HIES and DHS.10 The TA will contribute to the direct 
costs of the surveys while technical inputs will be provided by the NSOs, SPC, and United 
Nations agencies and not be charged to the TA. Supporting the ongoing implementation of the 
Pacific household survey program will remain a key element of ADB’s support for statistics in the 
region, as it is for other development partners. The TA will meet the cost of selected surveys in 4 
countries with others being supported by the DMC and/or other development partners. 
 
17.  Improving  national  accounts  and  balance  of  payments.  National  accounts  and 
balance of payments represent the most important annual series of economic statistics in the 
region. The TA will support the development of explicit plans in each Pacific DMC for improving 
the production of economic statistical series. This is an area of statistical production, which is 
particularly poor in the Pacific. These explicit plans for improving economic statistics will be 
supported  by  targeted  short-term  technical  support  provided  by  the  PFTAC,  SPC,  and  the 
Australian  Bureau  of  Statistics.  In  addition,  a  group  of  eminent  Pacific  national  accounts 
practitioners  will  be  seconded  to  NSOs  within  the  region  to  assist  with  preparing  national 
accounts and balance of payments accounts and helping build staff capacity. Their salaries will 
be met by their originating NSOs, and the TA will support the travel costs of the program. 
 
18.  Building capacity. Implementation of the TYPSS will include direct capacity building of 
NSOs by regional organizations, development partners, and regional statisticians. In developing 
the TYPSS, agreement has been reached on the gap between what statistics should and are 
being prepared in Pacific DMCs. The TA will support capacity development by undertaking a 
capacity assessment and needs assessment in each of the Pacific DMCs. In some instances, this 
will build on the work already completed in some NSOs on compiling the national statistics 
strategies. The outcomes of the assessments will be utilized by the University of the South Pacific 
in revising its statistics certificate and diploma programs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000. Of the total amount, $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The 
remainder  of  the  cost  ($150,000)  will  be  through  in-kind  contributions  by  participating 
governments. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. A national consultant (national program 
coordinator) will (i) maintain the TYPSS monitoring framework, (ii) assist the chair of the PSSC, 
(iii) review technical papers, and (iv) assist ADB manage and monitor the performance of the TA. 
                                                 
10 The funds for the household survey program will be pooled by development partners and further supplemented by       
Pacific DMC funds. External funding from other development partners may be country specific as each survey is 
being  prepared.  The  TYPSS  PSSC  will  oversee  the  implementation  of  the  survey  program  and  its  funding 
requirements.

5 
Eight  person-months  of  national  consultant  input  will  be  required  to  assist  in  the  program 
management. The consultant will have expertise in specific areas of statistics, household surveys, 
and operations in an NSO. The consultant will be hired on an individual basis by ADB. 
 
22.  The SPC will be contracted as a firm on the basis of single-source selection to implement 
outputs 1–3. The SPC is the regional organization responsible for technical support to Pacific 
DMCs  in  statistics  under  the  Pacific  Plan.  SPC  will  be  responsible  for  coordination  of 
development assistance on statistics in the region against the Phase 1 Action Plan. SPC will: (i) 
manage the delivery of HIESs, (ii) manage the delivery of the DHSs, (iii) oversee the preparation 
of regional capacity assessments and training needs analysis, (iv) manage the south–south 
cooperation program, and (v) assist with the preparation of economic statistics strategies in each 
country. The SPC will coordinate and support the work of each country’s NSO, provide expert 
advice  and  management  oversight  of  each  activity,  and  will  meet  reasonable  costs  for  the 
delivery of the outputs in accordance with the budget.  
 
23.  The development partners supporting statistics in the Pacific have endorsed the TYPSS 
and the TYPSS Action Plan Phase 1, and are represented in the PSSC. The PSSC coordinates 
technical support from the PFTAC, United Nations agencies, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 
and New Zealand Statistics in alignment with the Action Plan Phase 1. Technical assistance by 
development partners will be provided and not be charged to the TA. The TA will meet the travel 
costs where necessary. In particular, the TA will support the travel cost of national statisticians in 
the region under secondment to other NSOs as a part of the TYPSS strategy to foster south-
south cooperation. SPC will act as the Secretariat for the TYPSS and there will be considerable 
overlap between their role as the region’s Secretariat and the services provided under the TA. 
 
24.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The project will be carried out over 40 months 
from January 2011 to August 2014. This aligns with phase 1 of the TYPSS. Financing of any 
activities funded by this proposed TA will commence in a participating Pacific DMC only after 
ADB  has  received  a  written  statement  of  no-objection  from  the  participating  Pacific  DMC 
government. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Any procurement will 
be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
If procurement of vehicles or equipment does occur, these will be transferred to the relevant 
government at the end of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis by 
the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Building Capacity for Statistics in the Pacific, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  National Program Coordinator 
1.  The national program coordinator (8 person-months intermittent) will have a degree in 
statistics  or  a  related  field.  He  or  she  will  have  experience  in  household  surveys  and  in 
operations of a national statistics office (NSO). He or she will support the implementation of the 
technical assistance (TA) and the operations of the Ten-Year Pacific Statistics Strategy (TYPSS) 
Pacific Statistics Steering Committee (PSSC). 
 
2.  The consultant’s tasks will include: 
(i)  assisting the Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) maintain the TYPSS 
monitoring framework, 
(ii)  assisting the chair of the TYPSS PSSC prepare and disseminate material for the 
biannual TYPSS PSSC meeting, 
(iii)  reviewing technical papers produced by the steering committee and coordinating 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and World Bank comments, and 
(iv)  assisting ADB monitor the performance of the TA. 
 
B.  Secretariat of the Pacific Community 
1.  Overview, Team Leadership, and Administration 
3.  The TA will require the services of a team of national and international consultants 
managed by the SPC to: (i) manage the delivery of household income and expenditure surveys 
(HIESs), (ii) manage the delivery of the demographic and health survey (DHS), (iii) oversee the 
preparation of regional capacity assessments and training needs analysis; (iv) manage the 
south–south cooperation program, and (v) assist with the preparation of economic statistics 
strategies in each country. The SPC will coordinate and support the work of each country’s NSO, 
providing expert advice and management oversight of each activity, and will meet reasonable 
costs for the delivery of the outputs in accordance with the budget. 
 
4.   The SPC Statistics for Development Programme will act as the implementing agency 
and its manager will act as the team leader, who will: 
(i)  direct and supervise the activities of each HIES, ensuring the timely delivery of 
the final report; 
(ii)  direct and supervise the activities of each DHS, ensuring the timely delivery of 
the final report; 
(iii)  be responsible for the collective work of the SPC team and for timely preparation 
of all formal written reports and financial management; and 
(iv)  report to the TYPSS PSSC on the effectiveness and collaboration with other 
development partners. 
 
5.  The financial monitoring specialist will be responsible for: 
(i)  the preparation of all budgets, 
(ii)  all financial and progress monitoring for the TA, 
(iii)  financial processing to ADB in accordance with its requirements, and

2.  Household Income and Expenditure Surveys 
 
7.  Scope  of  consulting  services.  In  conducting  HIESs,  utilize  the  methodology  and 
approach agreed to by the heads of statistics and planning in Pacific developing member 
countries will be utilized, as will specialists from within the region (as required). 
 
8.  The survey specialist will be responsible for assisting with:  
(i)  preparing HIES survey plans;  
(ii)  compiling  HIES  questionnaires  for  specific  country  requirements,  utilizing  the 
Pacific standardized questionnaire as the base;  
(iii)  managing the implementation of a sample survey and testing its veracity;  
(iv)  overseeing the preparations for the HIESs; 
(v)  editing and auditing the survey responses; and 
(vi)  assuring the quality in preparation of the HIES report. 
 
9.  The household income and expenditure survey specialist will be responsible for assisting 
with:  
(i)  overseeing the hiring of supervisors and enumerators; 
(ii)  providing training for supervisors and enumerators; and  
(iii)  managing the implementation of the surveys, data entry, and coding. 
 
3.  Demographic and Health Surveys  
10.  Scope of consulting services. The TA will require the services of a team of national 
and international consultants managed by SPC to prepare and publish DHS reports in selected 
countries. The SPC Statistics for Development Programme will organize and coordinate all 
activities to ensure their successful implementation. The expertise of a public health specialist, 
demographer, and survey specialist will be utilized. Throughout project implementation, the 
consultants will provide policy guidance to ensure that the outputs can be utilized for formulating 
an evidence-based basic social policy. All consultants will ensure transfer of skills in the process 
of supporting the preparation of the reports. All consultants will closely collaborate in extending 
assistance to staff at the implementing agencies.  
 
11.  The survey specialist will be responsible for assisting with:  
(i)  preparing a DHS survey plan;  
(ii)  compiling a DHS questionnaire for specific country requirements, utilizing the 
Pacific standardized questionnaire as the base;  
(iii)  managing the implementation of a sample survey and testing its veracity;  
(iv)  overseeing the preparations for the DHS survey; 
(v)  editing and auditing the survey responses; 
(vi)  overseeing the hiring of supervisors and enumerators; 
(vii)  providing training for supervisors and enumerators; 
(viii)  managing the implementation of the survey, data entry, and coding; and 
(ix)  assuring the quality in preparation of the DHS report.

Appendix 3  11 
12.  The public health specialist will be responsible for assisting with: 
(i)  assessing of DHS data and analysis activities carried out in the region;  
(ii)  writing relevant chapters of the DHS report for each country; and 
(iii)  the overall production of the DHS report in each of the countries, with other team 
members. 
 
13.  The demographer will be responsible for assisting with: 
(i)  assessing the policy implications of the DHS data utilizing experience across the 
region, and 
(ii)  preparing the whole report. 
 
14.  Detailed tasks. In consultation with the governments and utilizing a collaborative writing 
approach with each government, SPC will prepare detailed DHS reports.  At a minimum, this will 
include: 
(i)  compilation and ratification of all DHS tables; 
(ii)  analysis of data, written for nondemographers and public health specialists; 
(iii)  policy implications of the analysis for government consideration; 
(iv)  peer review of the draft report; 
(v)  preparation of a final report; and 
(vi)  preparation of briefing materials to standards of the Marshall Islands briefing 
material. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
